SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a German national
Text: spouse of a German,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a German national
Text: minor unmarried child of a German,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a German national
Text: parent of a minor unmarried German for the purpose of care and custody if the German’s habitual residence is in the federal territory. In derogation from section 5 (1) no. 1 it is to be granted in the cases covered by sentence 1 nos. 2 and 3. In derogation from section 5 (1), no. 1, it is to be granted as a general rule in the cases covered by sentence 1 no. 1. In derogation from section 5 (1) no. 1, the temporary residence permit may be granted to the parent of a minor unmarried German who does not possess the right of care and custody of said child, if the family unit already exists in the federal territory. Section 30 (1) sentence 1 nos. 1 and 2, sentence 3 and subsection 1 sentence 1 applies accordingly in the cases covered by sentence 1 no. 1.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a German national
Text: As a rule, the foreigner is to be granted a permanent settlement permit if he or she has possessed a temporary residence permit for three years, the family unit with the German continues to exist in the federal territory, there is no public interest in expelling the foreigner and the foreigner has a sufficient command of the German language. Section 9 sentences 2 to 5 applies accordingly. In all other cases, the temporary residence permit is extended as long as the family unit continues to exist.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a German national
Text: Sections 31 and 34 apply subject to the proviso that the foreigner’s residence title is replaced by the habitual residence of the German in the federal territory. The temporary residence permit granted to a parent of a minor unmarried German for the purpose of care and custody is to be extended also after the child has come of age as long as the child lives with the foreigner in a family household and is in education or training which leads to a recognised school, vocational or higher education qualification.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a German national
Text: Section 36 applies accordingly to other dependants.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a German national
Text: (repealed)

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: For the purpose of subsequent immigration to join a foreigner,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: the foreigner must have a permanent settlement permit, an EU long-term residence permit, a temporary residence permit, an EU Blue Card, an ICT Card or a Mobile ICT Card, or he or she must be entitled to stay in the federal territory in accordance with section 18e and

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: sufficient living space must be available. Sentence 1 no. 2, section 5 (1) no. 1 with the exception of the existence of sufficient health insurance coverage and section 27 (3) sentence 1 do not apply if

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: the foreigner to be joined by dependants has an EU Blue Card,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: immediately before the EU Blue Card was granted, the holder of the EU Blue Card had an EU Blue Card issued by another member state of the European Union, and

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: the family unit existed in the other member state of the European Union.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: The requirements of section 5 (1) no. 1 and subsection (1) no. 2 may be waived in the case of the spouse and the minor unmarried child of a foreigner who possesses a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 23 (4), section 25 (1) or (2), a permanent settlement permit in accordance with section 26 (3) or a permanent settlement permit in accordance with section 26 (4) after being granted a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 25 (2) sentence 1 second alternative. In the cases covered by sentence 1, these conditions are to be waived where

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: the application for a residence title required in connection with the subsequent immigration of dependants is filed within three months of final recognition as a person entitled to asylum or final granting of refugee status or subsidiary protection or after the issuance of a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 23 (4) and

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: it is not possible for the foreigner and his or her dependants to live together as a family unit in a state which is not a member state of the European Union and to which the foreigner or his or her dependants have special ties. The time limit stated in sentence 2 no. 1 is also met if the foreigner files the application on time.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: The temporary residence permit may only be granted to the spouse and the minor child of a foreigner who possesses a temporary residence permit in accordance with sections 22, 23 (1) or (2) or section 25 (3) or (4a) sentence 1, section 25a (1) or section 25b (1) for reasons of international law, on humanitarian grounds or in order to safeguard political interests of the Federal Republic of Germany. Section 26 (4) applies accordingly. The subsequent immigration of dependants is not permitted in the cases covered by section 25 (4), (4b) and (5), section 25a (2), section 25b (4), section 104a (1) sentence 1, section 104b and section 104c.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: In derogation from section 5 (1) and section 27 (3), the temporary residence permit is to be granted to the spouse and the minor unmarried child of a foreigner or the minor unmarried child of the foreigner’s spouse if the foreigner has been granted temporary protection in accordance with section 24 (1) and

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: the family unit in the country of origin has been broken up as a result of the foreigner having fled said country and

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: the dependant is admitted from another member state of the European Union or is located outside of the European Union and is in need of protection. The granting of a temporary residence permit to other dependants of a foreigner who has been granted temporary protection pursuant to section 24 (1) is subject to section 36. Section 24 applies to dependants who are admitted in accordance with this subsection.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of dependants to join a foreigner
Text: The requirement of subsection (1) no. 2 is waived for the spouse or minor unmarried child of a foreigner who has an EU Blue Card, an ICT Card, a Mobile ICT Card or a residence title under sections 18a, 18b, 18c (3), 18d, 18f, 19c (1) for employment as an executive, manager, business specialist, academic, visiting academic, engineer or technician in a research team of a visiting academic or as teaching staff, pursuant to section 19c (2) or (4) sentence 1 or section 21.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: A foreigner’s spouse is to be granted a temporary residence permit if

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: both spouses are at least 18 years of age,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the spouse is able to communicate in the German language at least on a basic level and

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the foreigner

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: possesses a permanent settlement permit,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: possesses an EU long-term residence permit,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: possesses a temporary residence permit in accordance with sections 18d, 18f or sections 25 (1) or (2) sentence 1 first alternative.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: has held a temporary residence permit for two years which is not subject to an ancillary provision pursuant to section 8 (2) or the subsequent issuance of a permanent settlement permit has not been ruled out by a rule of law; this does not apply to a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 25 (2) sentence 1 second alternative,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: has a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 7 (1) sentence 3 or Divisions 3, 4, 5 or 6 or sections 37 or 38, if the marriage existed at the time said permit was granted, and the foreigner’s stay in the federal territory is expected to exceed one year; this does not apply to a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 25 (2) sentence 1 second alternative,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: possesses a temporary residence permit pursuant to section 38a and the marriage already existed in the member state of the European Union in which the foreigner has the status of a long-term resident, or

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: has an EU Blue Card, an ICT Card or a Mobile ICT Card. Sentence 1 nos. 1 and 2 has no bearing on issuance of the temporary residence permit if the requirements of sentence 1, no. 3 (f) are met. Sentence 1 no. 2 has no bearing on issuance of the temporary residence permit if

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the foreigner holds a residence title pursuant to section 23 (4), section 25 (1) or (2), section 26 (3) or possesses a permanent settlement permit in accordance with section 26 (4) after being granted a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 25 (2) sentence 1 second alternative and the marriage already existed at the time when the foreigner established his or her main ordinary residence in the federal territory,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the spouse is unable to provide evidence of a basic knowledge of German on account of a physical or mental illness or disability,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the spouse’s need for integration is discernibly minimal within the meaning of a statutory instrument issued pursuant to section 43 (4) or the spouse would, for other reasons, not be eligible for an integration course pursuant to section 44 after entering the federal territory,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: by virtue of his or her nationality, the foreigner may enter and stay in the federal territory without requiring a visa for a period of residence which does not constitute a short stay,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the foreigner has an EU Blue Card, an ICT Card, a Mobile ICT Card or a residence title under sections 18a, 18b, 18c (3), 18d, 18f, 19c (1) for employment as an executive, manager, business specialist, academic, visiting academic, engineer or technician in a research team of a visiting academic or as teaching staff, section 19c (2) or (4) sentence 1 or section 21,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the spouse is unable or cannot reasonably be expected to undertake efforts to acquire a basic command of the German language before entering the country due to the specific circumstances of the individual case, or

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the foreigner was the holder of an EU Blue Card or a temporary residence permit under sections 18a, 18b, 18d, 19c (1) for employment as an executive, manager, business specialist, academic, visiting academic, engineer or technician in a research team of a visiting academic or as teaching staff, section 19c (2) or (4) sentence 1 or section 21, immediately before being granted a permanent settlement permit or an EU long-term residence permit.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: In derogation from subsection (1) sentence 1 no. 1, the temporary residence permit may be issued to avoid particular hardship. If the foreigner holds a temporary residence permit, the other conditions stipulated in subsection (1) sentence 1 no. 3 (e) may be waived; the same applies if the foreigner holds a national visa.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: By way of derogation from section 5 (1) no. 1 and section 29 (1) no. 2, the temporary residence permit may be extended for as long as the marital cohabitation continues.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: If a foreigner is married to several spouses at the same time and lives together with one spouse in the federal territory, no other spouse will be granted a temporary residence permit pursuant to subsection (1) or subsection (3).

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: If the foreigner is entitled to stay in the federal territory in accordance with section 18e, the spouse does not need a residence title if it has been established that the spouse resided in the other member state of the European Union lawfully as the foreigner’s dependant. The requirements stipulated in section 18e (1) sentence 1 nos. 1, 3 and 4, and the grounds for denial pursuant to section 19f apply accordingly to the spouse.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Independent right of residence for spouses
Text: If marital cohabitation ends, the spouse’s temporary residence permit is extended by one year as an independent right of residence unrelated to the purpose of the subsequent immigration of dependants if

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Independent right of residence for spouses
Text: marital cohabitation has lawfully existed in the federal territory for at least three years or

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Independent right of residence for spouses
Text: the foreigner has died during marital cohabitation in the federal territory and the foreigner possessed a temporary residence permit, permanent settlement permit or EU long-term residence permit up to that time, unless the foreigner was unable to apply for an extension in time for reasons beyond his or her control. Sentence 1 does not apply if the foreigner’s temporary residence permit may not be extended or if the foreigner may not be granted a temporary residence permit or EU long-term residence permit because this is precluded by a rule of law on account of the purpose of residence or by an ancillary provision attaching to the temporary residence permit pursuant to section 8 (2). (1a) If the foreigner has an EU Blue Card, subsection (1) applies to the foreigner’s spouse subject to the proviso that the time period referred to in subsection (1) sentence 1 no. 1 is also deemed to have been fulfilled if marital cohabitation has lawfully existed for at least two years in the federal territory and before that for at least one year in another member state of the European Union.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Independent right of residence for spouses
Text: The requirement in subsection (1) sentence 1 no. 1 for marital cohabitation to have existed lawfully for three years in the federal territory or lawfully for two years in the federal territory in accordance with subsection (1a) is to be waived if necessary to enable the spouse to continue his or her residence in order to avoid particular hardship, unless an extension of the foreigner’s temporary residence permit is not permitted. Particular hardship is deemed to apply especially if the marriage is not valid or has been suspended under German law because the spouse was a minor when he or she married, if the obligation to return to the country of origin resulting from the termination of marital cohabitation threatens to substantially harm the foreigner’s legitimate interests, or if continuing marital cohabitation is unreasonable due to the harm to the foreigner’s legitimate interests; in particular this is to be assumed if the spouse is the victim of domestic violence. Such legitimate interests also include the well-being of a child living with the spouse as part of a family unit. In order to avoid abuse, extension of the temporary residence permit may be denied if the spouse relies on benefits under Book Two or Book Twelve of the Social Code for reasons for which he or she is responsible.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Independent right of residence for spouses
Text: In derogation from section 9 (2) sentence 1 nos. 3, 5 and 6 the spouse is also to be granted a permanent settlement permit if the spouse’s subsistence is ensured after the termination of marital cohabitation by maintenance payments from the foreigner’s own funds and the foreigner possesses a permanent settlement permit or an EU long-term residence permit.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Independent right of residence for spouses
Text: Without prejudice to subsection (2) sentence 4, claiming benefits under Book Two or Book Twelve of the Social Code does not preclude extension of the temporary residence permit. The temporary residence permit may thus be extended as long as the conditions for granting the permanent settlement permit or EU long-term residence permit have not been met.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: The minor unmarried child of a foreigner is to be granted a temporary residence permit if the parents or the parent having the sole right of care and custody hold one of the following residence titles:

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 7 (1) sentence 3 or Divisions 3 or 4,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 25 (1) or (2) sentence 1 first alternative,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: a temporary residence permit in accordance with sections 28, 30, 31, 36 or 36a,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: a temporary residence permit in accordance with the other provisions, with the exception of a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 25 (2) sentence 1 second alternative,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: an EU Blue Card, an ICT Card, a Mobile ICT Card, a permanent settlement permit or

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: an EU long-term residence permit.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: If the minor unmarried child is aged 16 or over and if he or she does not relocate the main ordinary residence to Germany together with his or her parents or the parent possessing the sole right of care and custody, subsection (1) only applies if the child speaks German or if it appears, on the basis of his or her education and way of life to date, that he or she will be able to integrate into the way of life in the Federal Republic of Germany. Sentence 1 does not apply if

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the foreigner possesses a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 23 (4), section 25 (1) or (2), a permanent settlement permit in accordance with section 26 (3) or possesses a permanent settlement permit in accordance with section 26 (4) after being granted a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 25 (2) sentence 1 second alternative,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the foreigner or the spouse living with him or her as a family unit has a permanent settlement permit in accordance with section 18c (3), an EU Blue Card, an ICT Card, a Mobile ICT Card or a temporary residence permit in accordance with sections 18a, 18b, 18d, 18f, 19c (1) for employment as an executive, manager, business specialist, academic, visiting academic, engineer or technician in a research team of a visiting academic or as teaching staff, section 19c (2) or (4) sentence 1 or section 21, or

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the foreigner or the spouse living with him or her as a family unit was the holder of an EU Blue Card or a temporary residence permit in accordance with sections 18a, 18b, 18d, 19c (1) for employment as an executive, manager, business specialist, academic, visiting academic, engineer or technician in a research team of a visiting academic or as teaching staff, section 19c (2) or (4) sentence 1 or section 21, immediately before being granted a permanent settlement permit or an EU long-term residence permit.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: As a general rule, where parents share the right of care and custody, a temporary residence permit pursuant to subsections (1) or (2) is also to be granted for the purpose of joining just one parent, if the other parent has consented to the child’s residence in Germany or if a competent authority has reached a legally binding decision to this effect.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: In all other cases, a minor unmarried child of a foreigner may be granted a temporary residence permit if necessary to prevent special hardship on account of the circumstances in the individual case concerned. The child’s well-being and the family situation are be taken into consideration. Section 36a applies to minor, unmarried children of foreigners who possess a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 25 (2) sentence 1 second alternative

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: If the foreigner is entitled to stay in the federal territory pursuant to section 18e, the minor unmarried child does not need a residence title if it has been established that the child stayed in the other member state of the European Union lawfully as the foreigner’s dependant. The requirements stipulated in section 18e (1) sentence 1 nos. 1, 3 and 4, and the grounds for rejection pursuant to section 19f apply accordingly to the minor child.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Children born in the federal territory
Text: In derogation from sections 5 and 29 (1) no. 2, a child who is born in the federal territory may be granted a temporary residence permit ex officio if one parent possesses a temporary residence permit, permanent settlement permit or EU long-term residence permit. Where both parents or the parent possessing sole right of care and custody hold a temporary residence permit, a permanent settlement permit or an EU long-term residence permit at the time of their child's birth, the child born in the federal territory is granted a temporary residence permit ex officio. A child born in the federal territory whose mother or father possesses a visa or is permitted to stay in the federal territory without a visa at the time of the child's birth is permitted to stay in the federal territory until the visa or the lawful period of stay without a visa expires.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: In derogation from section 5 (1) no. 1 and section 29 (1) no. 2, the temporary residence permit granted to a child is to be extended as long as a parent possessing the right of care and custody holds a temporary residence permit, permanent settlement permit or EU long-term residence permit and the child lives together with the said parent as part of a family unit, or if the child would have a right of return pursuant to section 37 if he or she left the federal territory.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: When a child comes of age, the temporary residence permit granted to the child becomes an independent right of residence which is unrelated to the purpose of the subsequent immigration of dependants. The same applies to the granting of a permanent settlement permit and an EU long-term residence permit or if the temporary residence permit is extended accordingly under section 37.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: The temporary residence permit may be extended as long as the conditions for granting the permanent settlement permit and the EU long-term residence permit have not yet been met.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Children's independent, permanent right of residence
Text: In derogation from section 9 (2), a foreign minor who has a temporary residence permit in accordance with this Division is to be granted a permanent settlement permit if he or she has had the temporary residence permit for five years on reaching the age of 16. The same applies if

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Children's independent, permanent right of residence
Text: the foreigner is of age and has been in possession of the temporary residence permit for five years,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Children's independent, permanent right of residence
Text: the foreigner has a sufficient command of the German language, and

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Children's independent, permanent right of residence
Text: the foreigner’s subsistence is ensured or he or she is in education or training which leads to a recognised school, vocational or higher education qualification.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Children's independent, permanent right of residence
Text: Periods in which the foreigner attended school outside of the federal territory are not normally counted towards the required duration of possession of a temporary residence permit as stipulated in subsection (1).

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Children's independent, permanent right of residence
Text: No entitlement to a permanent settlement permit pursuant to subsection (1) applies if

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Children's independent, permanent right of residence
Text: there is a public interest in expelling the foreigner which is based on the foreigner’s personal conduct,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Children's independent, permanent right of residence
Text: the foreigner has been sentenced to a term of youth custody of at least six months or a prison term of at least three months or a fine of at least 90 daily rates in the past three years due to an intentionally committed offence, or if a term of youth custody has been suspended or

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Children's independent, permanent right of residence
Text: the foreigner’s subsistence cannot be ensured without claiming benefits under Book Two or Book Twelve of the Social Code or juvenile welfare under Book Eight of the Social Code, unless the foreigner is in education or training which leads to a recognised school or vocational qualification. The permanent settlement permit may be granted or the temporary residence permit extended in the cases covered by sentence 1. As a rule, if, in cases covered by sentence 1 no. 2, the foreigner is placed on probation or the term of youth custody is suspended, the temporary residence permit is extended until the end of the probationary period.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Children's independent, permanent right of residence
Text: The requirements stipulated in subsection (1) sentence 2 nos. 2 and 3 and subsection (3) sentence 1 no. 3 are to be waived if the foreigner is unable to fulfil them on account of a physical or mental illness or disability.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of parents and other family members
Text: In derogation from section 5 (1) no. 1 and section 29 (1) no. 2, a temporary residence permit is to be issued to the parents of a minor foreigner who possesses a temporary residence permit pursuant to section 23 (4), section 25 (1) or (2) sentence 1 first alternative, a permanent settlement permit pursuant to section 26 (3) or a permanent settlement permit under section 26 (4) after being granted a temporary residence permit pursuant to section 25 (2) sentence 1 second alternative, if no parent possessing the right of care and custody is resident in the federal territory.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of parents and other family members
Text: Other family members of a foreigner may be granted a temporary residence permit for the purpose of subsequent immigration to join the foreigner if necessary in order to avoid exceptional hardship. Section 30 (3) and section 31 apply accordingly to adult family members and section 34 applies accordingly to minor family members.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration of parents and other family members
Text: A temporary residence permit allowing the subsequent immigration of dependants may be granted to the parents of a foreigner who was granted an EU Blue Card, an ICT Card, a Mobile ICT Card or a residence title in accordance with sections 18a, 18b, 18c (3), 18d, 18f, 19c (1) for employment as an executive, manager, business specialist, academic, visiting academic, engineer or technician in a research team of a visiting academic or as teaching staff pursuant to section 19c (2) or (4) sentence 1 or section 21 for the first time on or after 1 March 2024; the same applies to the parents of the foreigner’s spouse, if the spouse resides permanently in the federal territory. The temporary residence permit in accordance with sentence 1 may only be granted if the requirement of section 5 (1) no. 1 is met.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: The spouse or minor unmarried child of a foreigner holding a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 25 (2) sentence 1 second alternative may be granted a temporary residence permit on humanitarian grounds. The same applies to the parents of a foreign minor holding a temporary residence permit in accordance with section 25 (2) sentence 1 second alternative, if no parent possessing the right of care and custody is resident in the federal territory; section 5 (1) no. 1 and section 29 (1) no. 2 do not apply. The above-mentioned groups of persons have no entitlement to subsequent immigration of dependants. Sections 22, 23 remain unaffected.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: Humanitarian grounds within the meaning of this provision exist, in particular, where

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: it has not been possible for a long time for a foreigner and his or her dependants to live together as a family unit,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: a minor unmarried child is affected,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: life, limb or liberty of the spouse, the minor unmarried child or the parents of a foreign minor are at serious risk in the state of residence, or

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: the foreigner, the spouse or the minor unmarried child or a parent of a foreign minor is seriously ill, in need of care because his or her autonomy or capabilities are impaired or because he or she has a severe disability. A qualified medical certificate must be submitted to substantiate the illness, need for care or the disability, unless there are other indications that the family member abroad is ill, in need of care or disabled. Every month, 1,000 national visas may be granted for temporary residence permits in accordance with subsection (1) sentences 1 and 2. Special attention is to be paid to the well-being of children. Where humanitarian grounds exist, special attention is to be paid to integration aspects.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: As a general rule, no temporary residence permit is to be granted under subsection (1) sentences 1 or 2 if

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: in the case of a temporary residence permit in accordance with subsection (1) sentence 1 first alternative, the spouses were not married before fleeing their home country,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: the foreigner who is to be joined by his or her dependant,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: has been incontestably sentenced to a prison term of at least one year for one or more intentionally committed offences,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: has been incontestably sentenced to a prison term or a term of youth custody for one or more intentionally committed offences against life, physical integrity, sexual self-determination or property or for resisting enforcement officers if the criminal offence was committed using violence, using a threat of harm to life or limb, or with guile, or if it constitutes an offence under section 177 of the Criminal Code; this also applies if the foreigner has committed serial offences against property even if the perpetrator did not use violence, threats or guile,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: has been incontestably sentenced to youth custody for at least one year for one or more intentionally committed offences and enforcement of the penalty has not been suspended on probation, or

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: has been incontestably convicted of one or more intentionally committed offences as defined in section 29 (1) sentence 1 no. 1 of the Narcotics Act (Betäubungsmittelgesetz),

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: it is not to be expected that the foreigner who is to be joined by dependants will have his or her temporary residence permit extended nor that he or she will be granted another residence title, or

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: the foreigner who is to be joined by dependants has applied for a border certificate.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: Section 30 (1) sentence 1 no. 1, (2) sentence 1 and (4) and section 32 (3) apply accordingly.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Subsequent immigration to join persons granted subsidiary protection status
Text: Section 27 (3) sentence 2 and section 29 (2) sentence 2 no. 1 do not apply. Division 7 Special rights of residence

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: A foreigner whose lawful habitual residence as a minor was in the federal territory is to be granted a temporary residence permit if

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the foreigner lawfully resided in the federal territory for eight years prior to his or her departure and attended school in the federal territory for six years,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the foreigner’s subsistence is ensured by his or her own economic activity or by a maintenance commitment into which a third party has entered for a period of five years and

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the application for the temporary residence permit is filed after the foreigner has reached the age of 15 and before he or she has reached the age of 21, and within five years of departure from the federal territory.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: Derogation from the requirements stipulated in subsection (1) sentence 1 nos. 1 and 3 is possible to prevent particular hardship. The requirements stipulated in subsection (1) sentence 1 no. 1 may be waived if the foreigner has acquired a recognised school-leaving qualification in the federal territory. (2a) Derogation from the requirements stipulated in subsection (1) sentence 1 nos. 1 to 3 is possible if the foreigner has been unlawfully forced into marriage by means of violence or threat of serious harm and has been prevented from returning to Germany, and he or she files the application for a temporary residence permit no more than three months after the coercive situation has ended and within five years of departure from the federal territory, and it appears, on the basis of the foreigner’s education and way of life to date, that he or she will be able to become integrated into the way of life in the Federal Republic of Germany. As a general rule, if the foreigner fulfils the requirements of subsection (1) sentence 1 no. 1, the foreigner is to be granted a temporary residence permit if he or she has been unlawfully forced into marriage by means of violence or threat of serious harm and has been prevented from returning to Germany, and he or she files the application for a temporary residence permit no more than three months after the coercive situation has ended and within 10 years of departure from the federal territory. Subsection (2) remains unaffected.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: The temporary residence permit may be denied

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: if the foreigner was expelled or could have been expelled when he or she left the federal territory,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: if there is a public interest in expelling the foreigner or

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: as long as the foreigner is a minor and his or her personal care in the federal territory is not assured.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: The fact that the foreigner’s subsistence is no longer ensured on the basis of his or her own economic activity or that the maintenance commitment no longer applies because the five-year period has expired does not preclude extension of the temporary residence permit.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: A foreigner who receives a pension from an institution in the federal territory will generally be granted a temporary residence permit if the foreigner lawfully resided in the federal territory for at least eight years prior to his or her departure.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: Former Germans

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: are to be granted a permanent settlement permit if they had been ordinarily resident as Germans in the federal territory for five years when losing their German nationality,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: are to be granted a temporary residence permit if they had been ordinarily resident in the federal territory for at least one year when losing their German nationality. The application for a residence title pursuant to sentence 1 must be filed within six months of becoming aware of the loss of German nationality. Section 81 (3) applies accordingly.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: Former Germans who are habitually resident abroad may be granted a temporary residence permit if they possess a sufficient command of the German language.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: In special cases, the residence title pursuant to subsection (1) or (2) may be granted in derogation from section 5.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: The pursuit of an economic activity is permitted within the period for filing an application specified in subsection (1) sentence 2 and, if an application is filed, until the foreigners authority decides on the application.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: Subsections (1) to (4) apply accordingly to foreigners who, for reasons beyond their control, have been treated as Germans by German bodies to date.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory

Text: Foreigners who have the status of long-term residents in another member state of the European Union are granted a temporary residence permit if they wish to stay in the federal territory for more than 90 days. Section 8 (2) does not apply.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Residence permit for long-term residents in other member states of the European Union

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory

Text: A temporary residence permit issued pursuant to subsection (1) may be subject to an ancillary provision pursuant to section 34 of the Ordinance on the Employment of Foreigners for no longer than 12 months. If the temporary residence permit is issued pursuant to subsection (1), the period referred to in sentence 1 begins when the holder is permitted to take up employment for the first time. After this period has elapsed, the temporary residence permit entitles the holder to pursue an economic activity. Division 8 Involvement of the Federal Employment Agency

SectionTitle: Approval of employment for a foreigner

Approval may be granted if it is determined by law, on the basis of the Ordinance on the Employment of Foreigners or an inter-governmental agreement.

Approval is granted without labour-market tests within the meaning of subsection (3) no. 3 unless the Ordinance on the Employment of Foreigners determines otherwise. (2a) Approval is deemed to have been granted if the Federal Employment Agency has determined for individual occupations or employment that, for a limited time, filling open posts in compliance with terms of employment set by collective agreement or by the Federal Employment Agency is reasonable in terms of labour market and integration policy (global approval) and the employer has provided assurance of compliance. The competent body under section 71 may disagree with the global approval in individual cases. In this case, section 72 (7) applies accordingly.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Approval of employment for a foreigner
Text: The Federal Employment Agency may give its approval to the employment of foreigners irrespective of their qualification as a skilled worker, if

(3a) The Federal Employment Agency may give its approval to the skilled employment of foreigners in Germany pursuant to section 20a (5) sentence 2, if the foreigners are not employed under less favourable terms than German nationals employed in an equivalent position

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Approval of employment for a foreigner
Text: For approval or a work permit to be granted, the employer must provide the Federal Employment Agency with information about the employment relationship, in particular the remuneration, working hours and other terms of employment, compulsory social insurance and the need for an authorisation to work in the occupation. Employers who employ or used to employ a foreigner must provide the information referred to in sentence 1 within a month of a request from the Federal Employment Agency.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Approval of employment for a foreigner

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Approval of employment for a foreigner
Text: Subsections (3) and (4) apply accordingly to work permits granted by the Federal Employment Agency. In all other cases, the legal provisions governing the approval by the Federal Employment Agency apply to the work permit in the absence of any law or statutory instrument to the contrary. The Federal Employment Agency may determine demand-oriented admission figures with regard to approving a residence title for seasonal work and for short-term employment subject to quotas and with regard to approving a seasonal work permit and a work permit for short-term employment subject to quotas.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: Approval pursuant to section 39 is to be denied if

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: important personal grounds relating to the foreigner exist, or

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: if the future employer or his or her representative as authorised by statutes or law has been subject to an incontestable fine within the past five years for a breach of section 404 (1) or (2) no. 3 of Book Three of the Social Code, or if they have been subject to an incontestable fine or convicted to a term of imprisonment for a breach of sections 10, 10a or 11 of the Act to Combat Clandestine Employment or of sections 15, 15a or 16 (1) no. 2 of the Act on Temporary Employment Businesses; this applies accordingly to the host entity in the case of an intra-corporate transfer pursuant to section 19 or 19b.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: Further, approval may be denied if

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the employer or the host entity has failed to meet legal obligations regarding social security, taxation, labour rights or working conditions,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: insolvency proceedings have been instituted against the employer’s or host entity’s assets aiming to wind up the employer or the entity and its business,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the employer or the host entity have been wound up in insolvency proceedings,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the institution of insolvency proceedings against the employer’s or host entity’s assets has been refused for lack of assets, and its business has been wound up,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the employer or the host entity does not pursue any economic activity,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the presence of the foreigner is aimed at or results in affecting labour management disputes or negotiations, or

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
Text: the business or the host entity were established for the main purpose of facilitating the entry and residence of foreigners for the purpose of employment; the same applies if the employment relationship was established mainly for this purpose.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Revocation of approval and withdrawal of the work permit
Text: The approval may be revoked and the work permit from the Federal Employment Agency withdrawn if the foreigner is employed on less favourable terms than comparable German nationals or the conditions stipulated in section 40 are met.

SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions

SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions

SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions

(1a) The Federal Government may determine, on the basis of the Ordinance on the Employment of Foreigners with the approval of the Bundesrat, that the Federal Employment Agency may, given specific conditions, approve the employment of nationals of specific states.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions
Text: The Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs may determine the following on the basis of the Ordinance on the Employment of Foreigners without the approval of the Bundesrat:

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions
Text: the conditions and the procedure for granting approval by the Federal Employment Agency; an alternative procedure for labour-market tests may be regulated as well,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions
Text: details concerning restriction of the approval on a time-, plant-, occupational and regional basis,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions
Text: cases covered by section 39 (2) and (3) where approval requires a labour-market test, for instance for the employment of skilled workers in geographic areas of the Federal Employment Agency to be determined and in certain occupations,

SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions
Text: occupations in which nationals of specific states are to be denied an EU Blue Card, because there is a lack of qualified workers in these occupations in the country of origin,

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions
Text: cases in which an employer who has violated statutory obligations related to employment, in particular obligations under labour, social insurance or tax law may be barred from the possibility of gaining the approval of or being granted work permits by the Federal Employment Agency to employ foreigners.

ChapterTitle: Entry into and residence in the federal territory
SectionTitle: Authorisation to issue statutory instruments and instructions
Text: The Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs may issue instructions to the Federal Employment Agency on implementing the provisions of this Act and the statutory instruments issued in connection with it, the provisions enacted by the European Union on access to the labour market and the intergovernmental agreements on the employment of workers.

Foreigners living lawfully in the federal territory on a permanent basis receive support in integrating into the economic, cultural and social life of the Federal Republic of Germany and are expected to undertake commensurate integration efforts in return.

A basic package of measures to promote integration (integration course) supports integration efforts by foreigners. The integration course is intended to successfully teach the German language and knowledge of Germany's legal system, culture and history to foreigners. In this way, foreigners are supposed to become acquainted with the way of life in the federal territory to such an extent as to enable them to act independently in all aspects of daily life, without the assistance or mediation of third parties.

The integration course comprises a basic and advanced language course of identical duration to provide sufficient command of the language and an orientation course to impart knowledge of the legal system, culture and history in Germany. The integration course is coordinated and carried out by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees, which may enlist the services of private or public organisations to this end. As a general rule, reasonable fees are to be charged for attending the integration course, according due consideration to the ability to pay. The person who is obliged to ensure the foreigner’s subsistence is also obliged to pay such a charge.

The Federal Government is authorised to regulate further details of the integration course, in particular the basic structure, the duration, the content and implementation of the courses, the criteria for selecting and approving course providers, the requirements and general conditions for proper and successful participation in the courses and for certifying such participation, including arrangements for the payment of costs and data processing in accordance with section 88a (1) and (1a), via a statutory instrument not requiring the approval of the Bundesrat. This excludes the examination and certification requirements of the final examinations, which are defined by the Federal Ministry of the Interior, Building and Community via statutory instruments not requiring Bundesrat approval.
(repealed)

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: A foreigner residing in the federal territory on a permanent basis is entitled to one-time enrolment in an integration course

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: upon receiving a temporary residence permit for the first time

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: for the purpose of gainful employment (sections 18a to 18d, 18g, 19c and 21),

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: for the purpose of subsequent immigration by dependants (sections 28, 29, 30, 32, 36, 36a),

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: on humanitarian grounds pursuant to section 25 (1), (2), (4a) sentence 3 or section 25b,

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: as a long-term resident pursuant to section 38a or

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: upon receiving a residence title under section 23 (2) or (4). Permanent residence is generally assumed if the foreigner is granted a temporary residence permit valid for at least one year or has held a temporary residence permit for more than 18 months, unless the stay is of a temporary nature.

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: The entitlement pursuant to subsection (1) expires one year after the residence title establishing the entitlement was granted or when that title expires. This does not apply if the foreigner was unable to register for an integration course within that period for reasons beyond his or her control.

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: The entitlement to take an integration course does not apply

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: to children, juveniles and adults who start or continue school education in the Federal Republic of Germany,

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: when the need for integration is discernibly minimal or

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: when the foreigner already possesses a sufficient command of the German language. In cases covered by sentence 1 no. 3, the entitlement to take an orientation course remains unaffected.

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: A foreigner who is not, or is no longer, entitled to take an integration course may be allowed to do so if space is available in the course concerned. This provision applies accordingly to German nationals who do not have a sufficient command of the German language and have special integration needs, as well as to foreigners

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: who have permission to remain pending the asylum decision,

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: whose deportation has been suspended under section 60a (2) sentence 3, or

SectionTitle: Entitlement to attend an integration course
Text: who have a temporary residence permit pursuant to section 24 or 25 (5).

SectionTitle: Obligation to attend an integration course
Text: Foreigners are required to take an integration course if

SectionTitle: Obligation to attend an integration course
Text: they are entitled to attend under section 44 and

SectionTitle: Obligation to attend an integration course
Text: they are unable to communicate at least at a basic level in the German language or

SectionTitle: Obligation to attend an integration course
Text: they do not have a sufficient command of the German language at the time a residence title is issued under section 23 (2), section 28 (1) sentence 1 no. 1, section 30 or section 36a (1) sentence 1 first alternative 1 or

SectionTitle: Obligation to attend an integration course
Text: they are receiving benefits pursuant to Book Two of the Social Code and the institution providing basic income support for jobseekers has asked them to take an integration course in accordance with section 15 (5) sentence 2 or (6) of Book Two of the Social Code,

SectionTitle: Obligation to attend an integration course
Text: they have special integration needs and the foreigners authority requires them to participate in an integration course, or

SectionTitle: Obligation to attend an integration course
Text: they belong to the group of persons referred to in section 44 (4) sentence 2 nos. 1 to 3, are receiving benefits under the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act (Asylbewerberleistungsgesetz) and the competent benefit authority asks them to participate in an integration course In cases covered by sentence 1 no. 1, the foreigners authority ascertains when issuing the residence title whether the foreigner is required to participate. In the cases covered by sentence 1 nos. 1 and 3, where foreigners are receiving benefits in accordance with Book Two of the Social Code for measures pursuant to section 15 of Book Two of the Social Code, the institution providing basic income support for jobseekers is, as a general rule, to follow the obligation imposed by the foreigners authority. Where, in individual cases, the institution providing basic income support for jobseekers decides otherwise, it is to notify the foreigners authority accordingly, which will then revoke the obligation. The obligation is to be revoked where it is unreasonable to expect a foreigner to attend a part-time course in addition to pursuing an economic activity. Further, when issuing a residence title pursuant to section 25 (1) or (2), the foreigners authorities may require a foreigner to take an integration course if he or she only has a basic command of the German language. (1a) Unless it is withdrawn or revoked, the obligation to take an integration course pursuant to subsection (1) sentence 1 no. 1 expires only if the foreigner has duly participated in the integration course.

SectionTitle: Obligation to attend an integration course
Text: The obligation to take an integration course does not apply to foreigners

SectionTitle: Obligation to attend an integration course
Text: who are in vocational training or any other form of training or education in the federal territory,

SectionTitle: Obligation to attend an integration course
Text: who furnish evidence of attending comparable education measures in the federal territory or

SectionTitle: Obligation to attend an integration course
Text: for whom attendance on a long-term basis is not feasible or reasonable. (2a) Foreigners having a temporary residence permit pursuant to section 38a are exempt from the obligation to take an orientation course if they prove that they have already participated in integration measures in another member state of the European Union in order to attain their legal status as a long-term resident.

SectionTitle: Obligation to attend an integration course
Text: Foreigners who fail to meet the obligation for reasons for which they are responsible or who fail to pass the final examination will be informed by the competent foreigners authority, before it extends the temporary residence permit, of the possible consequences of their actions (section 8 (3), section 9 (2) sentence 1 nos. 7 and 8, section 9a (2) sentence1 nos. 3 and 4 of this Act, section 10 (3) of the Nationality Act (Staatsangehörigkeitsgesetz). The foreigners authority may take administrative enforcement measures to enjoin the foreigner to meet the obligation to take an integration course. If the obligation to take an integration course is not met, the prospective charge to cover costs may also be levied in advance in a single sum by issuing an official notice of fees.

As a general rule, the integration course is to be flanked by additional integration measures organised by the Federation and the Länder, in particular social education and migration-specific advising services. The Federal Ministry of the Interior, Building and Community or the body appointed by it is developing a nationwide integration programme which identifies, in particular, the existing integration measures for foreigners and ethnic German resettlers which are available from the Federation, Länder, local authorities and private organisations, and makes recommendations on the further development of the integration measures. The Länder, local authorities, the federal, Land and municipal foreigners commissioners and the Federal Government Commissioner for Matters Related to Ethnic German Resettlers are involved in developing the nationwide integration programme and in compiling informational materials on existing integration measures. As a rule, religious communities, trade unions, employers’ associations, voluntary welfare organisations and other social interest groups are also to be involved.

SectionTitle: Job-related language training; authorisation to issue statutory instruments
Text: Integration in the labour market may be promoted by means of job-related German language training courses. As a rule, these courses build on the general language training provided in the integration courses. Job-related language training is coordinated and carried out by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees. The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees enlists private or public institutions to run the job-related language training courses.

SectionTitle: Job-related language training; authorisation to issue statutory instruments
Text: Foreigners are obligated to take a job-related language training course if they are receiving benefits pursuant to Book Two of the Social Code and the institution providing basic income support for jobseekers has asked them to take such a course in accordance with section 15 (5) sentence 2 or (6) of Book Two of the Social Code, Labour market integration benefits pursuant to Book Two of the Social Code and active job promotion benefits under Book Three of the Social Code remain unaffected.

SectionTitle: Job-related language training; authorisation to issue statutory instruments
Text: The Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs is authorised to regulate, by means of a statutory instrument not requiring the approval of the Bundesrat, and in agreement with the Federal Ministry of the Interior, Building and Community, further details of the job-related language training, in particular the basic structure, the target groups, the duration, the content and implementation of the courses, the criteria for selecting and approving course providers, and the requirements and general conditions related to access to and proper and successful participation in the courses, including the final certificates and arrangements for the payment of costs, and the processing of data in accordance with section 88a (3).

SectionTitle: Information and advisory services; power to issue statutory instruments and pre-departure integration
Text: A nationwide advisory service will be set up starting 1 January 2026 to provide easily accessible advice on labour and social welfare law free of charge to third-country nationals. This service is intended for third-country nationals already residing in the federal territory as well as those who are ordinarily resident abroad and would like to work in the federal territory. Starting in calendar year 2026, advising, language courses, information about life in Germany and transnational assistance (pre-departure integration measures) may be offered in selected third countries. These services are intended for third-country nationals who are ordinarily resident abroad and would like to take up employment in the federal territory. The Federal Government website “Make it in Germany” will continue to be used to provide information for specific target groups on the need for skilled workers and on the immigration process in order to recruit skilled workers from third countries, and communications and support structures for recruiting skilled workers in the framework of “Make it in Germany” in Germany and abroad will be strengthened. The information, communications and support services are directed at employers in Germany and at third-country nationals already residing in the federal territory as well as those who are ordinarily resident abroad and would like to work in the federal territory.

SectionTitle: Information and advisory services; power to issue statutory instruments and pre-departure integration
Text: The competent authority for implementing the advisory service referred to in subsection (1) sentences 1 and 2 is the Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs. It may delegate the implementation of the advisory service to third parties. The competent authority for planning the pre-departure integration measures referred to in subsection (1) sentences 3 and 4 is the Office of the Federal Government Commissioner for Migration, Refugees and Integration. The task of implementing pre-departure integration measures pursuant to subsection (1) sentences 3 and 4 may be delegated to third parties. The competent authority for implementing the tasks referred to in subsection (1) sentences 5 and 5 is the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Climate Action in coordination with the participating ministries. It may delegate implementation of these tasks to third parties.

SectionTitle: Information and advisory services; power to issue statutory instruments and pre-departure integration
Text: The Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs is authorised to regulate, by means of a statutory instrument not requiring the approval of the Bundesrat, further details of the financing of the advising on labour and social welfare law, in particular the details concerning the provision of services, the approval periods, the application procedure, the conditions and the procedure for institutions to transfer benefits to third parties, the delegation of implementation to a third party, details concerning monitoring the use of funds and the evaluation. Sentence 1 does not apply to the pre-departure integration measures or the tasks referred to in subsection (1) sentences 5 and 6.

The foreigners authority may take measures to facilitate the departure of a foreigner who is enforceably required to leave the federal territory; in particular, it may oblige the foreigner to take up residence at a place of its designation.

A foreigner may be prohibited from leaving the federal territory in appropriate application of section 10 (1) and (2) of the Passport Act (Passgesetz). In all other cases, foreigners may be prohibited from leaving the federal territory only if they intend to enter another state without possessing the necessary documents and permits. The departure ban is to be lifted as soon as the reason for its imposition ceases to apply.

SectionTitle: Prohibition and restriction of political activities
Text: Foreigners may pursue political activities within the bounds of the general statutory provisions. A foreigner’s political activities may be restricted or prohibited if they

SectionTitle: Prohibition and restriction of political activities
Text: impair or endanger the development of informed political opinion in the Federal Republic of Germany, the peaceful co-existence of Germans and foreigners or of different groups of foreigners in the federal territory, public safety and order or any other substantial interests of the Federal Republic of Germany,

SectionTitle: Prohibition and restriction of political activities
Text: may be counter to the foreign policy interests of the Federal Republic of Germany or its obligations under international law,

SectionTitle: Prohibition and restriction of political activities
Text: contravene the laws of the Federal Republic of Germany, particularly in connection with the use of violence,

SectionTitle: Prohibition and restriction of political activities
Text: are intended to promote parties, other organisations, establishments or activities outside of the federal territory whose aims or means are incompatible with the fundamental values of a system of government which respects human dignity.

SectionTitle: Prohibition and restriction of political activities
Text: A foreigner’s political activities are prohibited if they

SectionTitle: Prohibition and restriction of political activities
Text: endanger the free and democratic constitutional system or the security of the Federal Republic of Germany or contravene the codified standards of international law,

SectionTitle: Prohibition and restriction of political activities
Text: publicly support, advocate or incite the use of violence as a means of promoting political, religious or other interests or are capable of inciting such violence or

SectionTitle: Prohibition and restriction of political activities
Text: support organisations, political movements or groups within or outside of the federal territory which have initiated, advocated or threatened attacks on persons or objects in the federal territory or attacks on Germans or German establishments outside of the federal territory.

Foreigners are required, when requested by the authority entrusted with checking persons’ identity, to present their passport, passport substitute or substitute identity document and enable the authority to check their faces against the photograph in the document. The same applies to the certificate confirming permission to remain pending the asylum decision pursuant to section 63 (1) sentence 1 of the Asylum Act. Foreigners holding an arrival certificate as referred to in section 63a (1) sentence 1 of the Asylum Act or one of the documents referred to in section 48 (1) no. 2 are required to present, upon request, the arrival certificate or document to the authority entrusted with checking the information stated therein and enable the authority to check their faces against the photograph in the document.
On request, foreigners are required to present and surrender
their passport, passport substitute or substitute identity document and

their residence title or a document confirming suspension of deportation to the authorities entrusted with enforcing the law on foreigners and to leave such documents with these authorities temporarily, where necessary in order to implement or ensure measures under this Act. On request, German nationals who also possess a foreign nationality are required to present and surrender their passport or passport substitute to the authorities entrusted with enforcing the law on foreigners and to leave the documents with these authorities temporarily if

they were denied a German passport under section 7 (1) of the Passport Act, the German passport was withdrawn under section 8 of the Passport Act or if they are subject to an order under section 6 (7) of the Act on Identity Cards (Personalausweisgesetz), if there are indications that they intend to leave the federal territory, or

the requirements for prohibiting them from leaving the country in accordance with section 10 (1) of the Passport Act are met and presenting, handing over and temporarily leaving the foreign passport or passport substitute with the authorities is necessary to carry out or ensure the departure ban.

To meet the obligation to have and present identification papers, it is sufficient for a foreigner who neither possesses a passport or passport substitute nor can reasonably be expected to obtain one to carry the certificate confirming a residence title or the suspension of deportation, if this document contains the foreigner’s personal details and a photograph and is marked to indicate that it is a substitute identity document.

Foreigners who do not possess a valid passport or passport substitute are required to cooperate in efforts to obtain the identity paper and to present, hand over and leave with the authorities entrusted with enforcing this Act all such documents, other papers and data carriers as may be of importance in establishing their identity and nationality and in establishing and enforcing a possibility of removing them to another state. If the foreigner fails to meet this obligation and there is factual evidence that he or she is in possession of such documents or data carriers, the foreigner and the objects in his or her possession and his or her home may be searched to seek such documents or data carriers. Searches of homes pursuant to sentence 2 may only be ordered by a judge or, in case of imminent danger, by the authorities charged with enforcing this Act; section 58 (9a) applies accordingly. The foreigner must tolerate this measure. (3a) The retrieval of data from data carriers, including mobile devices and cloud services, is permitted for the purpose of ensuring analysis in accordance with subsection (3b) if it is necessary to establish the foreigner’s identity and nationality and to establish and enforce the possibility of removal since the foreigner has no valid passport, passport substitute or other suitable proof of identity. The foreigner must provide the access data required for the permissible retrieval of data from of data carriers. (3b) Analysis of the data retrieved is only permitted as far as necessary to establish the foreigner’s identity and nationality and to establish and enforce the possibility of removing him or her to another state in accordance with subsection (3) and the purpose of the measure cannot be achieved by more lenient means. Where there is factual evidence that analysing data carriers would only provide information about the core area of private life, the measure is not permissible. No information about the core area of private life which are acquired in the course of analysing data carriers may be utilised. Records thereof are to be deleted immediately. A written record is to be made of the fact of their acquisition and deletion. The data carriers may be analysed only by employees who are qualified to hold judicial office. (3c) Retrieved data are to be deleted immediately as soon as they are no longer needed to establish the foreigner’s identity and nationality and to establish and enforce the possibility of removal. The retrieval, analysis and deletion of data is to be documented. Suitable technical and organisational measures as required by Articles 24, 25 and 32 of Regulation (EU) 2016/679 are to be taken to prevent unauthorised access to the retrieved data.
Where the passport requirement (section 3 (1)) is waived pursuant to section 5 (3) or section 33, a substitute identity document is issued. Subsection (3) remains unaffected.

If the foreigner does not provide the access data needed to analyse devices used for telecommunications purposes, the commercial providers of telecommunication services or those involved in the provision of such services may be required, where the statutory conditions for processing the data are met, to provide information about the data used to protect access to devices or to storage devices located in these devices or separate from them (section 174 (1) sentence 2 of the Telecommunications Act (Telekommunikationsgesetz)).
The foreigner is to be informed about the request for information in advance.
